medium: Red and black lacquer with engraved-gold decoration and sand lacquer inkstone
title: Inkstone with Fitted Box
text: One of the more unusual uses of lacquer during Ming and Ch'ing was the production of inkstones. This circular stone has the right texture and porosity to make a good grinding utensil yet it is lighter and easier to carry than a stone or ceramic version. The circular cover of the fitted box is decorated with the "filled-in and engraved-gold" technique (<I>tian-ch'i<I>). It displays ginkgo leaves, longan berries, cherries, and lychee on top with a more formal lotus scroll motif decorating its side register. All of these auspicious plants are outlined in gold and the general style can be seen as a revival of the Wan-li period (1573-1619). The bottom of the base bears the mark of Lu T'ung, a late eighteenth-early nineteenth-century lacquer artist.
description: flat circular covered box with squared off sides; lacquered organic motif at top and sides of cover, band of similar design carried through to base edge; brown lacquer ground, black interior
